metadata.title: Online Resource Electronic Supplemental Material 1 Changes of myocardial gene expression and protein composition in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy after immunoadsorption with subsequent immunoglobulin substitution

location.addrLine: partner site Greifswald, Universitätsmedizin Greifswald Friedrich-Ludwig-Jahn-Straße 15a
partner site Greifswald, Universitätsmedizin Greifswald Friedrich-Ludwig-Jahn-Straße 15a

body_text.text: In total 162 DCM patients with LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <45%) and symptoms of chronic HF according to New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II and III underwent IA/IgG in the University hospital Greifswald between January 2004 and May 2008. Patients had not suffered from active infectious diseases, cancer, chronic alcoholism, postpartum cardiomyopathy, or HF due to known origins (e.g. primary valvular disease). All patients received stable oral medication for HF according to ESC guidelines [5, 10, 13] and medication was kept stable for the duration of this study with exception of dose adjustments for diuretics (Table 1) .

Among all patients we excluded coronary heart disease by angiography as well as acute myocarditis by endomyocardial biopsy (EMB), in accordance with Dallas criteria [2] and immunohistological stainings [2, 4, 8, 9] . Myocardial biopsies were obtained for clinical reasons for diagnosis of DCM according to guidelines [4] and for assessment of myocardial infections and inflammation after IA/IgG at baseline (BL) and during follow-up after 6 months (follow up, FU). Transcriptome and proteome analyses were performed from endomyocardial restoring samples which were no longer needed for routine diagnostics. Sufficient material for extraction was available from a subset of these patients (total mRNA: n=33, protein: n=23) at BL and FU which were partially used in the analysis of the prediction study previously described [1] .

Written informed consent was obtained by each patient and the protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Greifswald, Germany (Reg.-Nr.: III UV 34/04). The investigation conforms to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki.

In all patients, IA was performed on five consecutive days using protein-A columns (Immunosorba®, Fresenius Medical Care AG, Bad Homburg, Germany) with a treatment regime described elsewhere [11] . After the final immunoadsorption session patients received 0.5g/kg humane intravenous immunoglobulins (Venimmun, Sandoglobulin, CSL Behring, Germany, or Octagam, Octapharma, Switzerland) to restore physiological IgG plasma levels [11] . The subgroups were not biased by the application of IgG products (p=0.49, Chi-square test, two sided).
body_text.section: Immunoadsorption and subsequent Immunoglobulin G substitution

body_text.text: The obtained raw data were analyzed with the Rosetta Elucidator software Determining the influence of IA/IgG on gene expression, the ratio of protein intensities at FU and BL per patient was calculated and analyzed by ratio-based statistics using the rank-product method [3] .

Before real-time PCR one-round T7-RNA polymerase-mediated linear amplification of 30 ng of total RNA was performed using the first part of the Two Cycle Target labeling protocol (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, California). The amplified RNA was reverse transcribed using a High-Capacity cDNA Reverse Transcription Kit (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California).
body_text.section: qRT-PCR according to Ameling et al. (2013) [1]

body_text.text: Real-time PCR analysis was performed for 14 patients (5 non-responders, 9 responders) and 6 controls [1] using a custom-manufactured TaqMan low-density array (TLDA; Applied Biosystems) that, in addition to the target genes, contained the common housekeeping genes β-2 macroglobulin (B2M), glucuronidase, beta (GUSB), TATA box binding protein (TBP), 18S rRNA, hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS), and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH). The TLDA cards were loaded with reaction mixes from control and patient samples, and PCR amplification was performed using a 7900 HT Sequence Detection System (Applied Biosystems). Thermal cycling was as follows: 2 minutes at 50°C; 10 minutes at 94.5°C, followed by 30 seconds at 97°C; and 1 minute at 59.7°C for 40 cycles. RT-PCR data were quantified using the SDS 2.3 software package (Applied Biosystems).
body_text.section: qRT-PCR according to Ameling et al. (2013) [1]

body_text.text: Using GUSB, HMBS, TBP and GAPDH as most stably expressed housekeeping genes normalization was performed with geNorm software [7, 14] . Relative quantities were calculated by calibrating to the sample with the highest expression.
body_text.section: qRT-PCR according to Ameling et al. (2013) [1]

body_text.text: Tissue composition has an impact on gene expression and protein levels. For representative reflection of ongoing molecular processes in the heart 3-4 biopsy specimens -which were no longer needed for routine clinical diagnostics -were used for transcriptome and proteome analyses. To estimate the fibrosis grade or the number of inflammatory cells other biopsy specimens (1mm 3 ) were used. The grade of fibrosis did not differ so much that a significant alteration upon therapy could be detected. However, the number of inflammation positive responders decreased significantly after therapy (see manuscript Table 2 ). In line with these results and already published data [12] we assumed fibrosis grade and inflammation to be parameters affected by IA/IgG. Adjustment for these parameters would thus mask the molecular alterations associated with IA/IgG and was therefore not performed.

However, a linear model adjusted for a) inflammation and b) fibrosis grade was conducted to screen for effects independent of these two cofactors via a linear regression approach using Genedata Analyst (v. 9.1.4a) (see Online Resource ESM 7 and ESM 8, respectively). We observed a stronger influence of the adjustment for inflammation and fibrosis on the data of responders compared to non-responders (see Online Resource ESM5 Supplemental Figure S3 ) emphasizing the assumption of these parameters being influenced by IA/IgG therapy.

FIGREF0.text: Quantitative proteomics and mass spectrometry according to Hammer et al. (2011)[6] Sample preparation Sample aliquots of 4 μg were diluted with 20 mM ammonium bicarbonate (ABC) until a final concentration of less than 1 M urea was reached. Following reduction by 2.5 mM DTT (1 h at 60°C) and alkylation by 10 mM iodoacetamide (30 min at 37°C) endoproteinase Lys-C (Sigma, Taufkirchen, Germany) in a ratio of 1:100 to substrate proteins was added and digestion proceeded for 3 h at 37°C. Subsequently, the samples were digested with trypsin (1:10) over night at 37°C for 18 h. The reaction was stopped with a final concentration of 1% acetic acid and the peptide mixtures were desalted on C-18 reverse phase material (ZipTip μ-C18 Millipore Corporation, Billerica, MA, USA). Peptides were eluted in 50% and 80% acetonitrile (ACN) each in 1% acetic acid. Pooled eluates were concentrated to 2 μl in a vacuum concentrator (5303, Eppendorf, Wesseling, Germany) and resuspended in 2% ACN in 0.1% acetic acid. Peptide separation was optimized using a non-linear 86 min gradient of 5-60% ACN in 0.1% acetic acid at a constant flow rate of 400 nl/min on a nanoAcquity UPLC reverse phase column (BEH130, C18, 100 μm x 100 mm, Waters Corporation, Milford, USA) operated on a nanoAcquity UPLC system (Waters). The eluate was directed into a LTQ-Orbitrab Velos mass spectrometer (Thermo Electron, Bremen, Germany) equipped with a nano electrospray ion source. After a survey scan in the Orbitrab analyzer (scan m/z 300-2000 Da), 10 MS/MS spectra were recorded in the LTQ in a data dependent mode with exclusion times of 90 sec. In total 46 samples were run. Database search Proteins were identified via a Elucidator web interface by an automated database search in a forward-reverse Swiss-Prot database rel.08/2012 (limited to human entries) using the Sequest algorithm (Sorcerer built 4.04, Sage-N Research Inc., Milpitas, CA, U.S.A.). Parent mass tolerance (MS) was set to 10 ppm and fragment mass tolerance 1 Da. Carbamido methylation of cystein was a fixed modification and methionine oxidation was considered as optional modification. Peptides were annotated at a false positive rate of 1% calculated in Elucidator based on PeptideTeller (Peptide Prophet). Protein identification was based on at least two significant peptides.

FIGREF1.text: version 3.3 (Ceiba solutions, Seatlle, WA, U.S.A.) employing the following workflow carried out with an in-house-created visual script: (i) feature detection, (ii) feature alignment across all 20 MS runs (adjusting for mean retention times shifts of 0.22 up to 2.6 min), (iii) filtering for features p < 0.05, (iv) feature annotation, (v) median normalization by a feature set containing search results and therefore discriminating features arising from single-charged contaminants, (vi) combination of signal intensities of technical replicates, (vii) filtering for unique peptides.
